If you replace "bitcoin" with "blockchain" in that last statement then I tend to agree with you.

Bitcoin didn't necessarily invent decentralized currency, either. It simply glued together a lot of other prior work in a novel way. Many people had been working on similar systems leading up to its release, they'd just not nailed it.

I read the http:// Pets.com reference as saying Bitcoin is one of the first, highly valued products built on top of blockchain technology (like http:// Pets.com was built on the internet) and there's a strong chance it dies just like http:// Pets.com did.

I don't think Bitcoin is efficient at anything right now, though... I strongly believe that other technology will leapfrog it (as happens in all technology) and the space will evolve. I hold hardly any Bitcoin though, so not a lot of skin in the game (or bias)

1. There are ways to to distributed consensus / blockchain / ledger stuff without necessarily requiring a built-in token (good point that not many do this right now, though) 2. Other than first-mover advantage, I don't see Bitcoin's special sauce?

Oh for sure... but I think that taste they're getting right now will lead to something that resembles the more traditional market in the long term rather than them continuing to invest in Bitcoin specifically.
RE: Countries adopting it, no. Maybe adopting the technology to power next-gen government-issued currencies. But Bitcoin itself, no.

Right, but the Bitcoin code is open source and blockchain as a decentralized system is easily reproducible. There is no secret sauce or business model that can't be replicated in seconds. The value add is from companies who have customers paying for value add on top of that.

I think the point being made is that Bitcoin itself (the token) doesn't have a business model that builds on top of the technology. Successful internet companies have taken the core tech and built profitable businesses around that.

"Bitcoin is an investment in blockchain in the same way that http:// Pets.com was an investment in the internet." - somehow missed this post, I tend to agree on the currency vs. technology POV.
